title: Norm (mathematics)
text:
In <a href="mathematics">mathematics</a>, a norm is a <a href="function%20%28mathematics%29">function</a> from a <a href="real%20number">real</a> or <a href="complex%20number">complex</a> <a href="vector%20space">vector space</a> to the nonnegative real numbers that behaves in certain ways like the distance from the <a href="Origin%20%28mathematics%29">origin</a>: it <a href="Equivariant%20map">commutes</a> with scaling, obeys a form of the <a href="triangle%20inequality">triangle inequality</a>, and is zero only at the origin. In particular, the <a href="Euclidean%20distance">Euclidean distance</a> of a vector from the origin is a norm, called the <a href="%23Euclidean%20norm">Euclidean norm</a>, or <a href="%23p-norm">2-norm</a>, which may also be defined as the square root of the <a href="inner%20product">inner product</a> of a vector with itself.
A pseudonorm or seminorm satisfies the first two properties of a norm, but may be zero for other vectors than the origin. A vector space with a specified norm is called a <a href="normed%20vector%20space">normed vector space</a>. In a similar manner, a vector space with a seminorm is called a "seminormed vector space".

Euclidean norm of complex numbers.
The Euclidean norm of a <a href="complex%20number">complex number</a> is the <a href="Absolute%20value%23Complex%20numbers">absolute value</a> (also called the modulus) of it, if the <a href="complex%20plane">complex plane</a> is identified with the <a href="Euclidean%20plane">Euclidean plane</a> formula_52 This identification of the complex number formula_53 as a vector in the Euclidean plane, makes the quantity formula_54 (as first suggested by Euler) the Euclidean norm associated with the complex number.

Zero norm.
In probability and functional analysis, the zero norm induces a complete metric topology for the space of <a href="measurable%20function">measurable function</a>s and for the <a href="F-space">F-space</a> of sequences with F–norm formula_94 
Here we mean by "F-norm" some real-valued function formula_95 on an F-space with distance , such that 
The "F"-norm described above is not a norm in the usual sense because it lacks the required homogeneity property.
Hamming distance of a vector from zero.
In <a href="metric%20geometry">metric geometry</a>, the <a href="discrete%20metric">discrete metric</a> takes the value one for distinct points and zero otherwise. When applied coordinate-wise to the elements of a vector space, the discrete distance defines the "<a href="Hamming%20distance">Hamming distance</a>", which is important in <a href="coding%20theory">coding</a> and <a href="information%20theory">information theory</a>. 
In the field of real or complex numbers, the distance of the discrete metric from zero is not homogeneous in the non-zero point; indeed, the distance from zero remains one as its non-zero argument approaches zero. 
However, the discrete distance of a number from zero does satisfy the other properties of a norm, namely the triangle inequality and positive definiteness. 
When applied component-wise to vectors, the discrete distance from zero behaves like a non-homogeneous "norm", which counts the number of non-zero components in its vector argument; again, this non-homogeneous "norm" is discontinuous.
In <a href="signal%20processing">signal processing</a> and <a href="statistics">statistics</a>, <a href="David%20Donoho">David Donoho</a> referred to the "zero" "norm" with quotation marks. 
Following Donoho's notation, the zero "norm" of is simply the number of non-zero coordinates of , or the Hamming distance of the vector from zero. 
When this "norm" is localized to a bounded set, it is the limit of -norms as approaches 0. 
Of course, the zero "norm" is not truly a norm, because it is not <a href="homogeneous%20function%23Positive%20homogeneity">positive homogeneous</a>. 
Indeed, it is not even an F-norm in the sense described above, since it is discontinuous, jointly and severally, with respect to the scalar argument in scalar–vector multiplication and with respect to its vector argument. 
<a href="Abuse%20of%20terminology">Abusing terminology</a>, some engineers omit Donoho's quotation marks and inappropriately call the number-of-nonzeros function the "L"0 norm, echoing the notation for the <a href="Lp%20space">Lebesgue space</a> of <a href="measurable%20function">measurable function</a>s.

However, the -th root of the norm (assuming that concept makes sense), is a norm.
Composition algebras.
The concept of norm formula_105 in <a href="composition%20algebra">composition algebra</a>s does "not" share the usual properties of a norm as it may be negative or zero for "z" ≠ 0. A composition algebra consists of an <a href="algebra%20over%20a%20field">algebra over a field</a> "A", an <a href="involution%20%28mathematics%29">involution</a> *, and a <a href="quadratic%20form">quadratic form</a> <a href="Degree%20of%20a%20field%20extension">formula_106</a> which is called the "norm".
The characteristic feature of composition algebras is the <a href="homomorphism">homomorphism</a> property of "N": for the product "wz" of two elements "w" and "z" of the composition algebra, its norm satisfies formula_107 For formula_55 formula_2 formula_57 and O the composition algebra norm is the square of the norm discussed above. In those cases the norm is a <a href="definite%20quadratic%20form">definite quadratic form</a>. In other composition algebras the norm is an <a href="isotropic%20quadratic%20form">isotropic quadratic form</a>.

Equivalence.
The concept of <a href="unit%20circle">unit circle</a> (the set of all vectors of norm 1) is different in different norms: for the 1-norm, the unit circle is a <a href="square%20%28geometry%29">square</a>, for the 2-norm (Euclidean norm), it is the well-known unit <a href="circle">circle</a>, while for the infinity norm, it is a different square. For any "p"-norm, it is a <a href="superellipse">superellipse</a> with congruent axes (see the accompanying illustration). Due to the definition of the norm, the unit circle must be <a href="convex%20set">convex</a> and centrally symmetric (therefore, for example, the unit ball may be a rectangle but cannot be a triangle, and formula_119 for a "p"-norm).
In terms of the vector space, the seminorm defines a <a href="topology">topology</a> on the space, and this is a <a href="Hausdorff%20space">Hausdorff</a> topology precisely when the seminorm can distinguish between distinct vectors, which is again equivalent to the seminorm being a norm. The topology thus defined (by either a norm or a seminorm) can be understood either in terms of sequences or open sets. If the vector space is a finite-dimensional real or complex one, all norms are equivalent. On the other hand, in the case of infinite-dimensional vector spaces, not all norms are equivalent.
Equivalent norms define the same notions of continuity and convergence and for many purposes do not need to be distinguished. To be more precise the uniform structure defined by equivalent norms on the vector space is <a href="uniformly%20isomorphic">uniformly isomorphic</a>.

Any <a href="locally%20convex%20topological%20vector%20space">locally convex topological vector space</a> has a <a href="local%20basis">local basis</a> consisting of absolutely convex sets. A common method to construct such a basis is to use a family ("p") of seminorms "p" that <a href="separation%20axiom">separates points</a>: the collection of all finite intersections of sets {"p" < 1/"n"} turns the space into a <a href="locally%20convex%20topological%20vector%20space">locally convex topological vector space</a> so that every p is <a href="continuous%20function">continuous</a>.
Such a method is used to design <a href="Weak%20topology">weak and weak* topologies</a>.
